::: {#comments .section}
[1.10. ]{.section-number}Comments[¬∂](#comments "Permalink to this heading"){.headerlink}
========================================================================================

As programs get bigger and more complicated, they get more difficult to
read. Formal languages are dense, and it is often difficult to look at a
piece of code and figure out what it is doing, or why. For this reason,
it is a good idea to add notes to your programs to explain in natural
language what the program is doing. These notes are called comments.

A **comment** in a computer program is text that is intended only for
the human reader - it is completely ignored by the interpreter. In
Python, the `#`{.docutils .literal .notranslate} token starts a comment.
The rest of the line is ignored. Here is a new version of *Hello,
World!*.

::: {.runestone .explainer .ac_section}
::: {#ac1_8_1 component="activecode" question_label="1.10.1"}
::: {#ac1_8_1_question .ac_question}
:::
:::
:::

Notice that when you run this program, it still only prints the phrase
Hello, World! None of the comments appear. You'll also notice that we've
left a blank line in the program. Blank lines are also ignored by the
interpreter, but comments and blank lines can make your programs much
easier for humans to parse. Use them liberally!

**Check your understanding**

::: {.runestone}
-   [To tell the computer what you mean in your
    program.]{#question1_8_1_opt_a}
-   Comments are ignored by the computer.
-   [For the people who are reading your code to know, in natural
    language, what the program is doing.]{#question1_8_1_opt_b}
-   The computer ignores comments. It's for the humans that will
    "consume" your program.
-   [Nothing, they are extraneous information that is not
    needed.]{#question1_8_1_opt_c}
-   Comments can provide much needed information for anyone reading the
    program.
-   [Nothing in a short program. They are only needed for really large
    programs.]{#question1_8_1_opt_d}
-   Even small programs benefit from comments.
:::
:::
